conclusion: The goal is to analyze the v-t graph to determine if the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds.
From t = 0s to t = 1s, the velocity is constant at v = 2 m/s.
From t = 1s to t = 2s, the velocity decreases linearly from v = 2 m/s to v = 0 m/s.
From t = 2s to t = 3s, the velocity continues decreasing linearly from v = 0 m/s to v = -2 m/s.
Variable linear motion occurs when the velocity of an object changes over time, meaning the acceleration is non-zero.
From t = 0s to t = 1s, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s, so acceleration = 0 m/s², indicating uniform motion (not variable).
From t = 1s to t = 2s, the velocity changes from 2 m/s to 0 m/s over 1 second, so acceleration = (0 - 2)/1 = -2 m/s², indicating variable motion.
From t = 2s to t = 3s, the velocity changes from 0 m/s to -2 m/s over 1 second, so acceleration = (-2 - 0)/1 = -2 m/s², indicating variable motion.
During the first 3 seconds, the particle has constant velocity (uniform motion) for the first 1 second and changing velocity (variable motion) for the next 2 seconds (from t=1s to t=3s).

Yes, the particle did undergo variable linear motion during the first 3 seconds, though not for the entire period. Specifically, it experienced uniform motion from t=0s to t=1s, followed by variable motion with constant negative acceleration from t=1s to t=3s.
